Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A fair die, with its faces numbered from <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is one in which each number is equally likely to land face up when the die is rolled. On a fair die, the probability that the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> will land face up is <math alttext="one sixth"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. A group of students wanted to investigate a claim about manipulating a fair die so that it favors one outcome. The claim states that if a fair die is put into an oven and baked at <math alttext="200 degrees Fahrenheit"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mi>°</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes, the inside of the die will begin to melt. When the die cools, the inside will be solid again, but with more weight toward the bottom. This shift in weight will cause the face that was up when the die cooled to land up more often that the other faces. The students obtained a fair die and baked it according to the preceding directions. The die cooled with the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> face up. After the die cooled, they rolled the die <math alttext="200"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times, and the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> landed face up <math alttext="43"><mstyle><mrow><mn>43</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times. Let <math alttext="p"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the population proportion of times the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> will land face up on the baked die if the die could be rolled an infinite number of times. (a) Clarke, one of the students, constructed a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for <math alttext="p"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as <math alttext="0.215 plus or minus 0.057"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.215</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.057</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Does the interval provide convincing statistical evidence that the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> will land face up more often on the baked die than on a fair die? Explain your reasoning.

Explain your reasoning.

(b) Aurelia, another student, suggested they conduct a significance test to investigate the claim. She tested the hypotheses <math alttext="H sub 0 colon p equals one sixth"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> versus <math alttext="H sub a colon p is greater than one sixth"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>></mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> at the significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. She obtained a test statistic of <math alttext="1.83"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.83</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with a <math alttext="p"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of <math alttext="0.033"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.033</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do the results of the significance test agree with the results of Clarke’s confidence interval in part (a)? Explain your reasoning.

(c) Two standard normal curves are shown below, one for the confidence interval calculated in part (a) and one for the significance test conducted in part (b). (i) For the confidence interval curve, label the critical values for the <math alttext="95 percent"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence level and shade the area that represents values in the outer <math alttext="5 percent"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (ii) For the significance test curve, label the critical value for the <math alttext="5 percent"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> significance level and shade the area representing the values of <math alttext="z"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that would lead to a rejection of the null hypothesis in part (b).

(d) Joachim, a third student, noted that the confidence interval in part (a) gives plausible values of the parameter as an interval between two values. He suggested that they develop a one-sided confidence interval because they were only concerned with whether the number <math alttext="6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was landing face up more often than expected, not less often. The one sided-interval will determine a value <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> such that all plausible values of <math alttext="p"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are greater than <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The formula for <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="L equals p hat plus z star times the square root of the fraction p hat times, open parenthesis 1 minus p hat, close parenthesis, over n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. (i) Determine the values of <math alttext="z star"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> needed to create the one-sided <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval. Then calculate the value of <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (ii) Do the results of Joachim’s one-sided confidence interval agree with results of Aurelia’s significance test in part (b)? Explain your reasoning.
